loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Riffat's Group

texts.en:
Riffat is a resident of Khanewal which is a small city in Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. Her house is located in the area of Shanti Nagar where she has been living with her family in a 3-room brick house for more than 10 years. 

Her husband has some cattle at home which he sells, after raising them, for profit. He also sells their milk to the community. He is very good with his customers and offers them good quality milk at reasonable prices. 

Riffat is a very skillful seamstress. She can sew designer and non-designer dresses very easily. She sews for her neighboring clients. She is also a very good housewife and carries out her household responsibilities very well. She has given birth to two sons. Both of them are below 10 years of age and don’t go to school because Riffat is not able to afford their education expenses now.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will utilize the loan in buying buffalo and goats to raise for selling. He has been operating this business for the past eight years and Riffat is hopeful that an investment will bring more profits to him. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she proved herself a responsible client by paying her installments on time and attending every meeting.  

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Riffat.

loans.use: To buy buffalo and goats to resell.

loans.name: Rukhsana's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana is a very supportive lady by nature. In addition to her household responsibilities, she also operates a grocery store adjacent to her home, she sells daily use items such as cooking oil, salt, sugar, etc. and she has a good number of clients in the region because she offers competitive prices. Her husband’s name is B. M. and he is a compounder. He works in a private clinic and cures the diseases of his patients. 

Rukhsana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her grocery store business. With the loan, she will buy more groceries in bulk quantity to provide better goods and more variety of products to her clients and improve her sales and income. She has been doing this business for the past 10 years and is very hopeful that an investment will put more money into her pocket by improving the condition of her business. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan year, she established a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. She belongs to Khanewal which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, famous for its agriculture industry

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business.

loans.name: Creciendo En Fe 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Eusebia’s family is composed of her spouse and three children, only one f them still lives at home. She tells us that she’s always been a hard-working woman and has always sought to have various businesses. She has  even run this vegetables and fruit stall for around 18 years, selling mostly vegetables and tropical fruits. This new loan will be invested to buy bags of peas and beans, vegetables and fruits, etc.

Eusebia is one of the group called 'Creciendo en Fe' 2 & 3, composed of nine businesswomen and one man, located  in the agricultural city of Hato Mayor. Her challenge is to work harder to give her children what they need, and her most favorite activity is to generate income.  She wants to have the opportunity to improve her business and see it grow into a successful one, with great income and sustainable enough to support her family.

loans.use: to buy peas, vegetables, plantains, fruit, etc.

loans.name: Nga's Group

texts.en:
Nga T. K., 50 years old with one child, is living with her family in Yen Hau village. Being a farmer, her main activity focuses on growing rice, corn, and vegetable in paddies of 4,500 square meter.  These agricultural products are used to meet her family food needs.  Besides, when having free time, she and her husband do extra work as carpenters. They make wooden family equipment such as desks, tables, beds, etc.  This helps her have more money to cover her family expenditures.  

To have  more capital to buy wood to use as a material, she  wants to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND  from  our credit program.

 Dan T. D., a 31-year-old  woman, has run a wood workshop for many years. She needs to have a loan of 6,944,000 VND to buy materials.

 Hung V. N. is 47 years old with two children. He is raising 10 pigs for meat.  He is in need of a loan of 6,944,000 VND to buy feed for them.

 Thach V. L. is 48 years old.  He has a wood workshop that makes wooden equipment to export to other provinces. He wants to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to buy materials.

loans.use: to buy wood to use as a material.

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera P. is a widow and has one 17-year-old child. She runs a small business selling various cosmetic items such as shampoos, hair dyes, soaps, and detergents. She has been in this business for 19 years. When Vera's husband died, she had to continue the business that he initially started. She worked hard, learned a lot, and finally was able to sustain the business and even open several more locations to make this business a success. She currently has five locations that provide jobs for 10 employees.

Vera is requesting a loan for 15,000 Grivnas to increase the assortment of shampoos, hair dyes, and soaps. Her business goal is to open one more location in her town. She wants to save enough money to be able to help her daughter attend college.

loans.use: To purchase shampoos, hair dyes, and soaps

loans.name: Doan's Group

texts.en:
Doan T. C. is 48 years old with three children who are in high school.  Growing up in Tam Giang commune where rice growing culture is very popular, she has a lot of experience in doing farming especially in growing rice and tomatoes. Every year, she can  get 8 millions VND profit from selling these agricultural products. Her  business has  strongly developed since she  began having loans from our  credit program  in 2008. Her loan size has gotten bigger over the years. Now she wants to have  a loan  of 7,392,000 VND to buy five more pigs to raise

 Pha T. N.  is  a 34-year-old farmer. She has run VAC form  which is a mixed farming activity including growing rice, raising chickens, catching fish and has made considerable profit  for many years. She wants to borrow  7,392,000 VND to buy  feed for chickens.

 De T. N. is 28 years old. She is raising  12 pigs for meat. She needs to have  a loan of 7,392,000 VND to improve her pigpen.

 Be T. N. is 44 years old. She also is raising 10 pigs for meat. She wants to  borrow 6,496,000 VND to buy  feed for them.

 Gia T. N. is 48 year old. She is growing corn and vegetables in a paddy of 3,600 square meters. She needs to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy five more pigs to raise.

loans.name: Tuyen's Group

texts.en:
Tuyen T. Tran is 23 year old with two children who are small. Ms Tuyen has had a wood workshop for many years.  Her wood workshop focuses on making tables for praying to ancestors. This is different from other workshops in her village. Therefore, she is always busy with   clients' orders. Although she gets tired, she is keen on doing this business, because, it can create 5,000,000 VND profit per month for her to use to support her family. To enlarge her workshop, she wants to borrow 5,152,000 VND  from our credit program.

Phuong T. N. is 38 years old. She has a small wood workshop that receives orders from a bigger workshop.  She wants to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to buy materials.

Huong T. N. is 25 years old. Being  a wood caver, she makes parts of equipment for big wood workshops. She needs to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to buy a small cutting machine.

Uoc T. N. is 46 years old. She is running a wood workshop that  makes high quality products  for export to  China. She needs to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND  to buy  a cutting machine.

loans.use: To enlarge her workshop.

loans.name: Gulzar's Group

texts.en:
Gulzar is a resident of Jaranawala, which is a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan. She has been living there with her family in a single room brick house for the past 12 years. Her husband works in a private firm for a low income and she operates an embroidery business to share the financial burden with him. She is very skillful in her work and receives regular orders from her neighboring clients every month. 

She is a mother of four sons. Her eldest son operates a sweetmeat business. He operates his small shop in the market and prepares many sweetmeat items to sell to his customers on profit. He has been doing this business for the past 10 years and has a good taste in his hands which his clients admire. 

Her second son works in a mill, The third is studying in class 9th while the youngest one stays at home. He is only 6 years old. Gulzar is also a very good housewife and does her household responsibilities very well. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her eldest son in improving his sweetmeat business. With the loan, he will buy ingredients such as milk, sugar, cooking oil and dried fruits to make sweetmeats in larger quantity which will help him increase his sales and earn better profits. Gulzar is hopeful that her son will make positive use of loan and improve his business. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. She has maintained a good credit behavior in every loan year. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Gulzar.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for sweetmeat selling business.

loans.name: Creciendo En Fe 1 Group

texts.en:
Johanna is one of the members of the "Creciendo en Fe" 1 (Growing with Faith) Group, which is formed by five micro-business people. All members sell clothes, natural products, shoes, food, etc. Johanna's family is formed by herself and four children, only one of whom lives with her. She lives in the north of Santo Domingo. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity you can't count on. The town also has a large Dominican and Haitian immigrant population who live with very limited resources. They love to listen and dance to music in their free time.

Johanna is very excited to receive her first loan with Esperanza Internacional. She plans to invest her new loan in her business. She sells silver jewelry. She will use her income to renovate her home and to purchase some needed items. She lives together with her husband and their only child.

loans.use: to buy silver jewelry for resale.

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana sells men's clothing at one of the markets in Melitopol city and has been in this business for 14 years. She has always tried to offer her clients a large variety of clothing at affordable prices.

Tatyana is married with two children and her clothing business is the only source of income for her family. She uses the profit to support her family and also her parents’ family to enable them to survive economically.

Tatyana has used micro-loans before and found them very helpful for her business. This time, she would like to borrow 20,000 Grivnas to purchase spring coats for sale.

loans.use: to purchase spring coats for sale

loans.name: Tinh's Group

texts.en:
Tinh T. N. is 53 years old with two grown children. Being a farmer, her main activities are growing rice and raising pigs for meat. Her business has been run for many years. Since beginning to receive loans in 2007, she bought a rice-hulling machine which turns raw rice into the one that Vietnamese people  use as daily food.  These services attract villagers come and make considerable income for her. During  her participation in our  credit program, she has  been a good re-payer. Now she wants to have a loan of 7,392,000 VND to improve her pig pen.

Chien T. N. is 52 years  old. She is running a shop that sells ready cooked food. She  needs to  borrow 7,392,000 VND to buy a glass cabinet to keep food hygienic.

Canh T. N. is 52 years old. She has a shop that sells rice in a local market. She wants  to borrow  7,329,000 VND to buy more rice to meet the demand of customers.

Duc T. N.  is 54 years old. She also has a shop that sells rice, corn, and beans. She wants  to have a loan of 7,392,000 VND to invest in her business.

loans.use: to improve her pig pen.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy additional  important things for his general store.

loans.name: Duc's Group

texts.en:
Duc T. N. is 48 years old with three children. Two of them are attending high school.  Being a cake maker, she  has opened a shop that sells her products in the local market. Every day, she can sell 1000 cakes with 150,000 VND profit. Besides, to take full advantage of leftovers, she raises 10 pigs  for meat.  Regarding to her attitude to our credit program, she is always a good re-payer. Currently, she wants to borrow 7,392,000 VND to buy materials  for making cakes.

 Hien T. N. is 48  years old. She is raising 10 pigs for meat. She needs to have 6,496,000 VND to buy feed for them.

 N. T. N. is 41 years old. She is breeding pigs for their offspring. She needs to have a loan of 6,496,000 VND to improve her pig sty. 

 Nam T. N. is 48  years old . She has a wood workshop  at her house. She is in need of 6,496,000 VND to buy materials.

 Tan T. N.  is 26 years old . She is running a shop that sells fresh fruit in the local market. She wants to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to buy more fruit to meet the demand of customers.

  Tuyet T. N. is 31 years old . She has a shop that sells clothes in  Yen Phu market. She needs to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to invest in her shop.

Nga T. V. is 31 years old. She has a small grocery shop in Yen Phu market. She wants to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to buy more kinds of products to attract more and more customers to come.

 Trang T. N.  is 21 years old . She makes popcorn to sell  wholesale. She wants  to have a loan of 5,152,000 VND to do maintenance on her popcorn making machine.

loans.use: to buy materials  for making cakes

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina belongs to Jaranwala which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a 2-room brick house with her family for the past 25 years. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her tassel-making business. She sells tassels to different laces and thread sellers in the market and earns good income. The tassels are mostly used for the designing of clothes and they give a good and attractive look to dresses. She has been operating this business for the past five years and the loan investment will enable her to make more tassels by buying beads and thread in bulk quantity. 

She is also a very responsible housewife and does her household work very well. Her husband’s name is A. A. and he works in a government organization. Robina has given birth to a son who is 17 years old and operates a grocery store. Through his shop he sells daily use items to his customers. 

Robina is a regular loan user and this is her 3rd loan application. She has maintained a good credit behavior in every loan year and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Robina.

loans.use: To buy beads and thread for tassel-making business.

loans.name: Gulbarchyn

texts.en:
Gulbarchyn S. is 27, married, and has three children. In her local area she is known as a very positive, hard-working and persistent person. She has been engaged in farming since 2002 and her husband helps in all activities.  Gulbarchyn cultivates beans and corn which allows her earn about 200,000 KGS in a year. With the revenues they were able to build a house and cultivate a personal plot of land near it.    

Gulbarchyn has applied for a loan of 40,000 KGS for purchasing mineral fertilizers to manure land. This will allow her to get a good harvest and raise the quality of her products. 

About Bai-Tushum: 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia M. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 42 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Cecilia and her husband own and operate a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a welding business in the local community. Cecilia has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Cecilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase materials and equipment. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase materials and equipment to be used in the business. This loan will be Cecilia's second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials and equipment for her welding business

loans.name: Ronalyn

texts.en:
Ronalyn V. is from the town of District 1, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is 24 years old and married with one infant child. To make a living, Ronalyn raises pigs for fattening and sale. Ronalyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her grown pigs.

In 2010, Ronalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Ronalyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:

To make a living, Milagros owns a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Milagros joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase additional food. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Milagros from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase goods for his general store

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 47 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Annabelle has a business making and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Annabelle joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to cook more products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Annabelle from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to cook more products to sell

loans.name: Rizza Joy

texts.en:
Rizza Joy A. is from the village of Namnama, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 18 years old and single. To make a living, Rizza Joy has a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She is just starting this business.

In 2011, Rizza Joy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Rizza Joy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Betania Group

texts.en:
Mwanaisha S., who is in her mid-thirties is married with two children.  She is a food vendor at a place called Ilala, some few kilometres from the small town called Kariakoo. She has been in this business for 10 years.  She works from 5:00am to 4:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Mwanaisha's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan to increase her food stock.  Her dream is to one day open a wholesale food shop.

Mwanaisha will share this loan with her loan group Bethania, which has total of 15 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable is paying back their loans.

In the picture, Mwanaisha is just in the second row, 1st from the right.

loans.use: To increase her stock of foods.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Annet is a thirty-nine-year-old widow with three children and  she owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been dealing in second-hand clothes for fifteen years starting with a capital of 300,000 shillings. She now has 2,500,000 shillings. Her hardship is low sales and her desire is to own a boutique. Annet needs the loan facility to buy second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothes for resale

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Carolina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Carolina owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal use products such as shampoo, soap & body lotions in the local community. Carolina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Carolina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carolina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Carolina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Carolina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more sacks of  charcoal.

loans.name: Galilaya Group

texts.en:
Mariam S., who is in her  mid-thirties, is single and has two children.  She has been selling fabrics, sarongs and cosmetics.  She works from 9:00am to 4:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Mariam's second loan fron Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to buy more fabrics and sarongs and also started selling cosmetics. She has successfully paid back her loan.  She hopes for another loan to further increase her stock.  Her dream is to one day build her own house and also send her children to college.

Mariam will share this loan with her loan group "Galilaya", which has a total of 15 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

Mariam is 1st on the left, first row, in an orange dress.

loans.use: To increase her stock of cloth and cosmetics.

loans.name: Florida

texts.en:
Florida P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 51 years old. Florida is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Florida owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Florida has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Florida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. Florida is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Florida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for her small business.

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en: Josephat is a fifty-two-year-old married man with seven children and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been selling  animal drugs for four years starting with 900,000 shillings and now has 3,000,000 shillings as working capital. His hardship is price fluctuations and his vision is to become a veterinary doctor. Josephat needs the loan to buy drugs and spraying equipment to sell.

loans.use: to buy drugs and  spraying equipment for resale.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta P. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 53 years old. Julieta is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Julieta owns & operates a specialized store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling children's products such as toys, candies, notebooks, and writing materials outside a school campus. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Julieta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Julieta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional  toys, candies, notebooks, and writing materials, etc.

loans.name: Mgombolwa Group

texts.en:
Conelia P., who is in her late twenties, is married with two children.  She has been running a general store for three years now.  She works from 6:00am to 8:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Conelia's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan to increase her shop inventory. Her dream is to one day go to Nairobi and make her own choice of ladies' clothes.

Conelia will share this loan to her loan group, "Mgombolwa", which has a total of 20 members.  The members of the group will hold each other  accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Conelia is 1st on the left front row.

loans.use: To increase her shop inventory.

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie C. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Virgie is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Virgie owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables in the community. Virgie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Virgie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Virgie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Virgie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a thirty-seven-year-old married man with one child and he inherited a house from his father in Kasese, Uganda. He has been dealing in hardware for five years starting with four million saved from his previous loan and now it is worth six million. His hardship is bad debtors and  his vision is building a commercial house. John is requesting a loan to buy cement, iron bars, nails, and iron sheets to sell.

loans.use: to buy cement, iron bars, nails and iron sheets.

loans.name: Casipher

texts.en: Casipher is 34 years old, married, with three children, living in her own house in Hioma, Uganda. She started by selling milk and from her savings she was able to start up a bar and lodging which she has operated for 8 years. Her hardship is working from rented premises and her dream is to build a hotel. Caipher needs the loan to pay rent.

loans.use: to pay rent.

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
Marciana C. is from the village of Del Pilar, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Marciana is married and has four children. To make a living, Marciana owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Marciana has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marciana joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Marciana is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products such as canned goods, biscuits, detergent, soap, and sugar. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Marciana from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products such as canned goods, biscuits, detergent, soap, and sugar.

loans.name: Thuyimanaye Group

texts.en: Rauben is a thirty-two-year-old married man with four children and he rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the butchery business for ten years starting with 100,000 shillings and now has 4,000,000 shillings as working capital. His hardship is high prices for goats and cows and his vision is constructing permanent butcher premises and educating his children. He is a member of "Thuyimanaye" group where each member guarantees the other. Rauben needs the loan facility to buy cows and goats for their meat.

loans.use: to purchase cows and goats for their meat.

loans.name: Mwale Group

texts.en:
Pili J., who is in her early forties, is married with five children.  She has been running a business selling fabrics,sarongs and "bites" for six years.  She works from 6:00am to 3:00pm. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Pili's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase her business stock, to pay school fees, buy sofa sets, a bed and for household expenses. She has paid back all her loans successfully.  She hopes for a loan to expand her business  stock.

Pili will share this loan with her loan group, "Mwale", which has a total of 17 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Pili is 1st on the right, front row. (the one on the left in orange, 1st row, is a daughter of one of the members, she is not a client)

loans.use: To expand her stock.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en: Brenda is a 28-year-old single mother of two children renting a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been in a retail shop for the last two years. She started with a capital of 200,000 shillings and increased to 700,000 shillings. Her hardship is low sales as a result of power shortages and her vision is to buy a generator and build a house. Brenda needs the loan to buy bread, soda and salt.

loans.use: to buy bread, soda and salt to sell

loans.name: Kimanga Group

texts.en:
Clementina J., who is in her late 50s, is married with six children.  She has been running a charcoal business for four years now. She works from 6:00 am to 7:00 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. 

This will be Clementina's fourth motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. She hopes to obtain a loan to increase her business. She used the previous loans to increase her stock. She has paid back all her previous loans successfully. She hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal stock. Her dream is to one day open a clothing shop. 

Clementina will share this loan with her loan group, Kimanga, which has a total of eight members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. 

In the picture, Clementina is in the back row on the right in a cream dress.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Efrena

texts.en:
Efrena is a 44-year-old married woman living in the town of Trinidad, Bohol. She has eight children, the oldest of whom is 28 years old. Four of her children still go to school. Efrena works hard to sustain their education.

Efrena sells gasoline. She has a small stall where she displays bottles of gasoline. She says her business is helpful because the gas station is quite far. Efrena's husband is a farmer and a driver. He tills land to plant and harvest rice crops. He also has a "habal-habal" (motorcycle transportation) business. 

Efrena wants to buy more gasoline to resell. She applied for a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used for purchasing farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase more gasoline and farm inputs

loans.name: Naseem Akhter's Group

texts.en:
A talented lady, Naseem Akhter is a seamstress by profession. She does sewing work for her neighboring clients. She receives a good number of orders every month and earns a good income after completing them. She is also a very good housewife and takes care of her household responsibilities very well. 
 
She is a resident of Jaranwala, which is a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a three-room brick house for the past 14 years. 

Her husband’s name is M. A., and he operates a lathe machine. He provides iron items and spare-part repair services to his clients. He is very good in his work and provides quality service.
 
Naseem has three children. All of them are young and getting their education. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy iron in larger quantities, which will enable him to repair more iron items and increase his monthly income.  

He has been operating this business for many years, and Naseem is very confident about the positive growth of his business after the loan investment. She is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her third loan application. She has maintained good credit behavior in every loan year and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with the book (called Asasah Passbook) is Naseem Akhter.

loans.use: to buy iron for the lathe business

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en:
Anabelle I. is from the village of Palomoc, Titay, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 34 years old. Anabelle is married and has five school-age children. To make a living, Anabelle owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste, in the local community. Anabelle has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2011, Anabelle joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anabelle is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anabelle from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nellie

texts.en:
Nellie J. is from the village of Palomoc, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. She is 60 years old, married and has 4 adult-aged children. Nellie owns and operates a business providing food services to local community members. Nellie has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Nellie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nellie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Nellie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Faith Group

texts.en:
Aisha M., who is in her early thirties, is single with three children. She has been running a food sales business for five years. She works from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Aisha's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to buy plates, chairs and food. She has successfully repaid her loan. Aisha hopes for a loan to buy a fridge to start selling cold drinks and ice cream. Her dream is to one day build her own house and to have her children obtain higher education.

Aisha will share this loan with her loan group, Faith, which consists of 20 members, who will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the photo, Aisha is 1st on the right, 3rd row with a  white head scarf.

loans.use: To buy a fridge.

loans.name: Mariame

texts.fr:
Femme de 47ans d’âge, mariée, mère de 6 enfants avec un niveau secondaire, elle se lance dans la vente d’habits pour femmes et enfants.

Depuis 1993, elle vend dans le marché et son activité marche bien. Elle a des ventes s de 20.000F à 35.000F par jour.
Le prêt qu’elle aura va lui permettre d’augmenter le stock de sa marchandise en achetant :
Les grands boubous pour dames, pantalons, blouses, robes pour filles, ensemble pour petits garçons, slips mixtes, serres têtes, barrettes, foulards.
Elle s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes dans un marché de la place.

Ses projets sont :
 -Faire agrandir son activité
 - Augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour devenir fournisseur.
- Faire venir des boubou , pagnes et articles pour enfants de l’Afrique de l’ouest.

Être dépendante financièrement est son soucis afin de subvenir aux besoins quotidien de sa famille.
texts.en:
This lady is 47 years old and a married mother of six with a secondary education; she sells women's and children's clothing for a living. She has sold her wares from the market since 1993, and generates daily sales between 20,000 F and 35,000 F. 
She will use her loan to purchase more stock, such as: large boubous (loose robes) for women, trousers, jackets, girls' dresses, children's suits, mixed pants, bras, hairpins and headscarves. She sources her goods from a market in the town square. 

Her plans are: to drive her business further, and to generate higher sales so that she may one day become a wholesaler herself, and import boubous, pagnes (wax cloths) and children's clothing from West Africa. 

Her main concern is that she remains financially independent so that she can meet her family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase the following from a wholesaler: large boubous (loose robes), trousers, girls' dresses, suits, hairclips and headscarves.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy A., from Catadman, Ozamiz City, is 29 years old and still single. She is currently employed at Appliance Center and also sells Avon products such as perfume, lotion, beauty products, etc. to her neighbors and friends. Engaged in this business for four years, she earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Joy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting her first loan of P50,000 PHP to help in the construction of their new home and to purchase more Avon products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living standard of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to help construct her new home and buy products for her Avon business

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora D., from the village of Gulayon, is 39 years old, married and has seven children, five of whom are students while the other two are yet too young to attend school. To make a living, Nora makes and sells food, her main source of income coming from making and selling cassava cake in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos a month.

In 2005, Nora joined PMPC, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC, she is requesting her ninth loan for 12,000 PHP to purchase materials for house renovation.

loans.use: to purchase materials for house renovation

loans.name: Firdos Wilayat Ali's Group

texts.en:
Firdos W. A. is 44 years old, married and has a son and three daughters, all of whom are getting their education in a nearby school. Firdos is a housewife who stays at home and performs household chores. She is a very caring mother and is bringing up her children well.

Firdos’ husband, W. A., is a retired air force employee. He now works in the fields growing different seasonal crops and earning income for the family. He also receives a pension every month. The family has lived in a three-room brick house for the past 22 years in Jaranwala, a small city located in Pakistan’s Punjab province and known for its agriculture.

Firdos has applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business, and this is her first loan application with them. With the loan, Firdos’ husband will buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides that will enable him to raise better crops. He has been farming for the past ten years, and Firdos is confident that an investment will bring more profit to her family and improve her family’s lifestyle.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called an “Asasah Passbook”) is Firdos.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia V. is 56 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. She is from the village of Del Pilar in the municipality of Cabatuan, a part of Isabela province on the island of Luzon. Nelia makes and sells food and drinks to passersby in the community. Nelia has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Nelia joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Nelia is requesting a new loan, her sixth from ASKI, of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make the foods she sells

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Mrs. Editha B. is 61 years old, a widow and has three adult-aged children. She is from the village of Cabungaan within the municipality of Clarin, a part of Ozamiz City in Misamis Occidental province on the Mindanao islands. Editha runs a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. She has been in business for ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Editha joined PMPC to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Editha is requesting a new loan, her third from PMPC, of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products for her retail store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family and save for future emergencies.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products for her store

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Mr. Nelson Q. is from the village of Bañadero, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is 50 years old, married, blessed with one child who is now school-aged. To make a living, he is presently engaged in ministerial work as a church pastor. He’s been engaged in this kind of ministerial work for 15 years already. He’s receiving an average love gift from the congregation in amount of not less than Php 10,000 a month for his ministerial activity. 

In July 2009, Nelson joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation.  As an active member of Paglaum MPC under the Regular Loan Program, Nelson has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php 10,000. He is now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 as his 3rd loan which will be used for traveling expenses for his church conference in Manila. He also joined Paglaum MPC because of the other services offered, especially savings and insurance.

 About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for traveling expenses for their church conference in Manila.

loans.name: Compressor Group

texts.en:
Christina B., who is in her mid-thirties, is married with three children.  She has been running a food vending stall for five years.  She works from 6:00am to 6:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Christina's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She wants a loan to increase her food stock. Her business is a few kilometres from the city centre.  Her dream is to one day build her own house and also send her children to good schools.

Christina will share this loan with her group "Compressor", which has a total of 18 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Christina is 1st on the right front row, wearing a blue dress.

loans.use: To increase her food stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Melita Gonzaga's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Melita G. is from the village of Gango, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. Melita is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Melita G.’s Group". 

Melita is 47 years old, married and blessed with seven children of whom three are now adults and the other four are school-aged. To make a living, she is presently engaged in “kangkong” (a vegetable like spinach) vending and laundry activity. Her husband is a farmer. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for 10 years already. She’s earning an average amount of not less than Php 2,000 a month from these activities. 

In September 2007, Melita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  As an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a micro-finance program that reaches out to rural communities, Melita has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php3,000. She is now requesting a loan of Php 5,000 as her 6th loan which will be used for  house repairs and renovation. She joined Paglaum MPC because she is very much interested in the programs and services offered, especially savings and insurance.

 About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to do house repairs and renovations.

loans.name: Jarlene Acupe's Group

texts.en:
Jarlene A. is from the village of Dimaluna, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Jarlene is married and has two school-aged children. Jarlene is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Jarlene A.’s Group".

To make a living, Jarlene owns and operates a hog raising business. She has been engaged in this business for two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jarlene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. Jarlene is requesting a loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


About Group Loans
In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
50-year-old Rebecca lives in the town of Trinidad, Bohol with her family. She is married and has five children. Her oldest child is now 30 years old and the youngest is 24.

Rebecca and her husband are both farmers. According to her, they have been engaged in rice farming for more than a decade. They earn approximately 6000 PHP a month from this farming.

Rebecca requested to borrow 20,000 PHP which she will use to purchase fertilizers and farming equipment.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and farming equipment.

loans.name: Limy

texts.en:
Mrs. Limy S. is from the village of Catadman, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old, married and blessed with 3 school-aged children. Limy presently operates a retail activity of rice retailing business. She’s been engaged in this business for 5 years and earns an average of not less than PHP 5,000 a month from it.

In August, 2010, Limy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities, Limy has successfully repaid a loan of PHP 7,000. She is now requesting an amount of PHP 10,000 as her 3rd loan, which will be used for purchasing more sacks of rice for her rice retailing business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs and in saving for future use, loan repayments, the children’s education and possible business expansions.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of rice for her rice retailing business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane J. is 36 years old.  She is married to Samuel Kipngetich, a tailor, and they have four children aged 16, 13, 11 and 6 years old.  Jane buys and resells milk in the Kabirsang trading center. She has been in this business for 6 years and earns a monthly income of Kshs 6,500. Besides selling milk she also sells maize from her crop farming.

This will be her second loan from KADET LTD. She successfully repaid her previous loan of Kshs 25,000.  She intends to use the new loan to pay the farmers for the milk that she sells. The anticipated profits will be used to improve the welfare of her family.

She hopes to educate her children to higher levels.

loans.use: to buy milk for resale

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy M. is from Mayor's Village, Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. Lucy owns and operates a business providing transport to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over eleven years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Lucy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC.

Lucy is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to buy housing materials for house improvements. This will be her 4th  loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy housing materials for house improvements

location.town: Mayor Village Lapasan, Clarin Mis Occ

loans.name: Wela

texts.en:
Ms. Wela C. is from the village of P3 Malaubang, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, single and has no dependents. Wela is presently engaged in guso (seaweed) culture and production. She also earns income from bunsod (a fish trap) and from video games as the caretaker. She’s been engaged in these businesses for 5 years and earns an average income of no less than PHP 4,000 a month.

In July, 2009, Wela joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities, Wela has successfully repaid a loan of PHP  8,000. She is now requesting an amount of PHP 5,000 as her 3rd loan, which will be used for the financing and maintenance of her seaweeds culture and production business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs and in saving for future use, loan repayments and possible business expansions.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Bernadith Cobero's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Bernadith C. is from the village of Capucao, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. Bernadith is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Bernadith C.’s Group". 

Bernadith is 35 years old, married and blessed with four children who are now school-aged. To make a living, she is presently engaged in farming and housekeeping activities. Her husband is a band saw laborer. She’s been engaged in this kind of activity for 10 years already. She’s earning an average amount of not less than Php 2,000 a month from these activities. 

On December 6, 2007, Bernadith joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  As an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a micro-finance program that reaches out to rural communities, Bernadith has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php 14,500. She is now requesting a loan of Php 5,000 as her 5th loan which will be used for  house repairs and renovation. She joined the program because she is very much interested in the savings, insurance and other benefits offered by Paglaum MPC.  

 About PMPC:

 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to do house repair and renovations.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in Jaranwala which is located in Punjab province, Pakistan, and known for its agriculture industry.  Her husband’s name is N. A. and he is involved in a dairy business. He gets milk from his dairy cow and sells it to the community. Raiza also supports her husband in getting milk from the cow. 
They both get up early in the morning and start their work. 

After finishing helping her husband, Razia cleans the whole house and prepares breakfast for her family. She makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy another dairy cow which will not only increase the milk productivity but also his monthly income as well.  Razia is hopeful that an investment will bring positive financial changes to her husband’s business. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Razia.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow for dairy business.

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva is a 37-year-old married woman living in the town of Trinidad, Bohol. She has three children aged 8, 4 and 2. Her husband is a fisherman.

Minerva sells barbecue. She has a small barbecue stand. She marinates chicken and pork early in the morning and cooks it in the late afternoon ready for selling. She also roasts hot dogs because that's popular among the kids in her neighborhood. Minerva also helps her husband sell all his catch.

Minerva requested to borrow 5000 PHP which she will use to purchase meat, charcoal and other ingredients for making barbecue. She wishes to expand her business further in the future.

loans.use: to purchase meat, charcoal and other ingredients for barbecue.

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to improve his loading business. With the loan, he will buy a new horse cart that will help him put more loads on it and earn better profits. He has been doing this business for past 30 years. Sajida is confident that an investment will bring her husband better profits and her family will be able to enjoy a better standard of living. 

Sajida is a housewife, stays at home and does her household chores. She is a very good administrator and manages her household expenses very well.  She has given birth to four sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is jobless and looking for a job while others are doing different kind of work to financially contribute to the family.  

Sajida is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan year, she has paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. She is hopeful that an investment will bring good changes to her husband’s business and increase his profits.

She lives in Jaranwala which is a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 40 years. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sajida.

loans.use: To buy a new horse cart for loading business.

loans.name: Baasansuren

texts.en:
Baasansuren is 26 years old, lives with his wife and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia.  They live together in a small house on their plot of land. His two sons are attending a local kindergarten. 

Baasansuren has operated a vegetable retail business for the last ten years and has gained a lot of experience. Since 2006 he has been renting a stall at “Kharkhorin” market. His wife helps his business during the day. As his business has grown, he has increased his inventory including fish, onions and fruit. Baasansuren is very hard-working person who is providing for his children’s future education and teaching them morals. 

He lives a little far from the market; therefore he is planning to purchase a car, using his savings. Baasansuren is requesting a loan to build an extension to his house entryway and will use part of the loan  to increase his working capital so he can buy more products for resale.

loans.use: to build an extension to his house entryway.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This borrower is 47 years old, married and has a child. She graduated from intermediate school. She has a beauty salon, and will use this loan to develop her shop and purchase new barber chairs, equipment and makeup. She has a good reputation in the market and has a lot of experience in the job. She has lots of clients because she relies on the most modern, updated styles in cutting hair and does arrangements for brides as well. This borrower has high ambition and motivation to develop her shop.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and makeup materials.

loans.name: Shahnaz Akhter's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz akhter lives in Jaranwala, a small city in the Punjab region of Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She and her family have been living there in a 2-room brick house for many years. Shahnaz has 4 sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is a driver and the 2nd eldest is a daily wage laborer. Her remaining children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. To financially assist her husband, Shahnaz sews clothes for neighboring clients. She is an expert at her work and receives regular orders every month.

Shahnaz has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband, who has been operating a poultry business for the past 25 years. He sells eggs and chickens to customers on profit. He has good business contacts in the region and gets regular orders from them. He will use this loan to buy chicks for his poultry business. Shahnaz is hopeful that an investment will be more profitable for him, enabling him to make more sales and profits.

Shahnaz is a regular lender with Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. She is a responsible client with a good credit record. Note: In the photo, Shahnaz Akhter is holding a book (called Asasah Passbook).

loans.use: to buy chicks

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene W. is 42 years old and married to Julius Mwololo.  She has run a poultry house at Komarock Estate for two years.  She also has a butchery business. These two businesses give her a monthly profit of Kshs 40,000 which is enough to meet her family’s needs. 

She was introduced to KADET by her friend who is an existing client. This loan will be her first loan with KADET and she plans to use it to buy more chicks for her poultry business. If the loan boosts the business, Irene plans to open two more poultry houses.

Irene describes herself as hardworking and dreams of having a big poultry house in the future.

loans.use: to buy more chicks

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn G. is from Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City. She is 51 years old, married and blessed with 6 children, 4 of adult age and 2 of school age. Marilyn is currently engaged in furniture making, with the help of her husband, and she also operates a food supplements business, selling to her neighbors and friends. Marilyn has been engaged in this business for 31 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC.

Marilyn is now requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more materials for furniture making. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living standards.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loans.use: to purchase materials for furniture making.

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran is a very supportive woman. She has been operating a milk sales business for the past 20 years to financially assist her family. She keeps a buffalo at her home, milks it and sells its milk to her community clients at reasonable rates. Sughran has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, to further improve her business. She plans to use the loan to buy another buffalo which will help her produce more milk and serve more clients. Sughran is hopeful that this loan will enable her business to grow and to produce more profit. Sughran's husband, A. G., is a daily wage laborer. Sughran has a son and a daughter. Her daughter is illiterate and her son is in 8th class. For the past 20 years, Sughran and her family have been living in a 2-room brick house in Jaranwala, a small city in the Punjab region of Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. Sughran is a regular lender with Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. She is a responsible client with a good credit record.

Note: In the photo, Sughran is holding a book (called Asasah Passbook).

loans.use: to buy another buffalo

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita D. is from Guba, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, she sells ready-to-wear clothing, primarily to her neighbors and friends. She has been engaged in this business for six years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase more ready-to-wear clothing to sell. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living standard of her family. 



About PMPC: 
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more ready-to-wear clothing to sell

loans.name: Lindie

texts.en:
Lindie G. is 31 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is residing at Mitimos, Rizal with her husband and her children. Lindie earns a living by running a barber shop. She has been in this business for many years. 

In 2006, Lindie joined Kiva field partner PMPC to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lindie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from PMPC, which she used to expand her business. Lindie is requesting a new loan of 4,500 PHP which will be used for educational purposes. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Lindie from PMPC.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
