loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn P. runs a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. She is 41 years old, married and has four school-aged children. They are from the town of District 1, Benito Soliven, Isabela. Jocelyn has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to invest in expanding her business. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Humphrey

texts.en:
Humphrey M. Z. is 53 years old and married. They have three children, aged between 19 years old and 4 years old, whom they hope to give good education to the university level. His business is located at Majengo estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many, many tourist attraction sites – not forgetting the Indian Ocean white beaches. 

Humphrey has been selling fish to the local people for the last 17 years and has managed to give employment to two people. He says that this business is profitable and his major challenges are financial constraints and the perishable nature of his products. However, he works hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to increase his stock of fish to meet the high demand of customers. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He also sees himself becoming a landlord some day. He describes himself as customer-friendly and a person who loves his work.

loans.use: to increase stock of fish.

loans.name: Andresa

texts.en: Andresa G. earns a living by running her own business selling motor spare parts. She has been managing her business for many years. Andresa is 59 years old, residing in Bitibut, Sapang Dalaga, with her husband and four adult children. In 2010, Andresa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Andresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from PMPC. This previous loan was used for medical purposes. Andresa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock to sell. This will be her second loan from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Lucrecia Carcueva Group's

texts.en: To make a living, Mrs. Lucrecia C. is presently engaged in housekeeping and buying and selling RTW [Ready to Wear clothes]. She is 43 years old, married and blessed with eight children: two married, two grown-up and four school-aged children. They are from the Barangay of Banadero, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She’s been engaged in her work for three years already. She’s earning an average of not less than 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Lucrecia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lucrecia is an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities, and has successfully repaid a loan of 3,000 PHP. She is now requesting a second loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to buy livestock feed and other supplies. She joined the program because she is very much interested in the savings, insurance and other benefits offered by Paglaum MPC. Lucrecia is the leader of a two member group accessing a loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Lucrecia C.’s Group". About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy drugs.

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina and her family live in a two-room brick house in Kasur, a small city in Pakistan known for its leather industry.  Sakina is a housewife, and takes care of her family by minding household responsibilities. In her spare time she also helps her husband, M. R., with his dairy business.  She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who wants to expand his business further. 

M. keeps two buffaloes and a dairy cow, and gets up early every morning to milk his animals. After that, he puts the milk in jars and delivers it to different homes in the area on his motor bike.  With this loan, he plans to buy another buffalo to increase the productivity of his business with the goal of being able to sell to more customers.

M. has been a dairy farmer for 18 years, and Sakina is confident that this loan will help to improve her husband’s business.  This will be her second loan from Asasah.  Over the course of her first loan, she proved to be a responsible client by paying her installments on time and attending every meeting.

Note: "In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sakina".

loans.use: to buy another buffalo for a small dairy farm

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley is widow, who lives in Northern Pob. Calamba. Her five adult-aged children now living independently. Shirley makes and sells  "sampaloc" (tamarind) candy as her primary business.  She has been making candy for 10 years and earns a monthly net income of about 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP).

In 2004, Shirley joined Kiva field partner PMPC to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  Shirley successfully repaid her previous loan of 30,000 PHP, and this will be her 15th loan from PMPC.   Shirley is requesting a new loan of 37,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make her candy.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients used to make tamarind candy

loans.name: Jerrypie

texts.en:
Jerrypie B. is from the town of District 1, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is 23 years old. Jerrypie is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Jerrypie owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $80 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Jerrypie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Mrs. Lolita A. is from the village of Lam-an, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old. Lolita is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, she owns and operates a cake baking business. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $160 a month for these activities.

In May 2009, Lolita joined PMPC under the Pension Loan Program to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a loan of 25,000 PHP.

Lolita is now requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock and ingredients for her cake baking business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use, loan repayment and the education of her child.

 About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Elmo

texts.en:
Elmo P. is from the village of Puntod Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. He is 44 years old and single. To make a living, Elmo plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elmo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Elmo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase his crop yield. This will be his 3rd loan from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Crispina M. is from the village of Gotocan Daku, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old, married, and has two adult-aged and one school-age child. She is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Crispina M.’s Group. 

To make a living, Crispina plants and harvests corn for sell. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Crispina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC.  

Crispina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be her 6th loan  from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a twenty-year-old ambitious man living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda, with a dream of building his own house in the next five years.

He has been providing motorcycle transportation for two years and his major challenge is having to remit 80% to his employer. He dreams of owning a motorcycle so as to increase his daily income, as the sector is very profitable. Robert needs the loan to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy earns a living by running a grocery store. She has been in this business for three years with a monthly net income of approximately $102. She is residing at Delapa, Sibutad, with her husband and two school-aged children. 

In 2010, Cristy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. 

She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock for the store. This will be her 6th loan from PMPC.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is an ambitious married man with three children, living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has been in the butcher business for four years. His business is now in its boom stage despite the challenge of the high costs of cows. Joseph's dream is to set up three shops in town. He needs this loan to buy more cows.

loans.use: to buy more cows to butcher.

loans.name: Wenniefreda

texts.en:
Wenniefreda D. G. is from the village of P-10 Manabay, Ozamiz City. She is 55 years old. Wenniefreda is married and has three adult-age children. To make a living, she owns and operates a retail store. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Wenniefreda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP To purchase variety of products such as can goods, shampoo etc. for her retail store. This will be her 6th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Tarcesio

texts.en:
Tarcesio is from the village of Caluya, Sapang Dalaga. He works as a cultivator of his own farm and that is his main source of income. He has been involved in this activity for many years. He is 57 years old and the father of three adult-aged children.

In 2011, Tarcesio joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting his 1st loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business for his children's education. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Orgil

texts.en:
Orgil is a 27-year-old taxi driver. He lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They do not have their own place to live and temporarily live in Orgil’s parents' house. Orgil’s wife, Ankhtsetseg, who is 24 years old, is looking after the baby at the moment.

Two years ago Orgil started running a taxi business which is his family’s only source of income. He is an experienced driver and he enjoys his work. He wants to buy a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and to live separately from his parents. The loan Orgil is requesting will be used to buy a ger.

loans.use: to buy a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent for his family.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more shawls for resale

loans.name: Teofila

texts.en:
Teofila works every day as a cosmetics dealer. She has been in this business for many years, and it is the main source of her income. She is 52 years old, married, and the mother of five children, four of whom are adults and one of whom is school-aged. She is now living in D'ban, Calamba, with her ill husband and her school-aged child.

In 2008, Teofila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teofila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Teofila is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used as start-up capital for a grocery store. This loan will be Teofila's fifth loan from PMPC.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: C6227 Dufatanye Group

texts.en:
Verene is 40 years old.  She is a widow with four children between the ages of 6 and 20. She is the representative of a group called "Dufatanye" in the local language. Verene and her group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses and earn more profits. Verene is the first person on the left in the picture. 

Verene owns a small shop that sells beans, sorghum, and other goods. She has three years of experience in her business. She employs one person in her business as a helper so that her business runs well. 

With the profits, Verene will build a comfortable house; she also needs a refrigerator, which will allow her to create a new business of selling cold soft drinks.

loans.use: to buy beans and sorghum

loans.name: Dossou

texts.fr: Monsieur a 50 ans et est marié.  IL a 4 enfants. Il habite quartier Attiegou. Pour pouvoir répondre aux besoins de ses enfants, il exerce comme activité la blanchisserie. Il compte 16 ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Il achète ces outils de travail au grand marché de Lomé.  Il a employé une personne dans la boutique. Il sollicite un prêt pour acheter  un lave linge, un fer à repasser, des cintres et les produits anti-rouilles.
texts.en: This man is 50 years old and married. He has four children and lives in the Attiegou district. To be able to respond to his children's needs he has a laundry business, which he has been running for 16 years. He buys his working materials at the large market in Lomé. He employs one person in the shop. He is requesting a loan to buy a washing machine, an iron, hangers and anti-rust products.

loans.use: To purchase products for his work

loans.name: Fawzi

texts.en: Fawzi is a 44-year-old married man living in Chtoura with his wife and four kids. Fawzi has been working in agriculture since 1990. He is a hard-working farmer: he and harvests and sells olives, and plants cucumbers in addition to selling his special-tasting olive oil, depending on his clients' opinions. Most of his clients are relatives, neighbors, and friends. This is Fawzi's first time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua. He needs the loan to buy new cucumber seeds for this season. Fawzi hopes to expand his business in order to provide a secure social and financial situation for his family. Fawzi hopes to give the best education to his kids, since he didn't get this opportunity.

loans.use: to buy new seeds to plant his land

loans.name: Anarkan's Group

texts.en:
Anarkan A., 54, is a leader of this group. She’s a resident of the town of Toktogul, in the western part of Kyrgyzstan. She has four children, only one of whom is financially dependent on her. The family business of cattle breeding and selling is the only source of income for the family, because Anarkan’s husband relies on a pension. The business was inherited from her husband’s parents, who gave them some cattle for further breeding.

Anarkan remembers painfully a time when all families involved in cattle breeding faced fierce economic conditions. Severe winters and extremely dry summers led to a lack of hay for cattle, and the volume of milk received fell dramatically. Anarkan was on the brink of giving up the business, but it was the only thing she had ever done, so she persisted, and survived that period.

It's been 25 years since she got involved in cattle breeding. Nowadays the monthly profit reaches 3000 soms. Some of the household electrical appliances are out of order, including Anarkan’s washing machine. She hopes to get this loan in order to purchase a new washing machine. Her dream is to purchase a nice piece of land and build a house.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a washing machine

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Mrs. Editha A. is from the Barangay of Dimaluna, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old, married and blessed with four children. Some are in school and others are now at their adult age. 

To make a living, she is engaged in aquaculture production, particularly in “guso” (seaweed) culture. She’s been engaged in this activity for 13 years already. She’s earning an average of not less than PHP 3,000 a month. 

In April 2007, Editha joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. As an active member of Paglaum MPC under the Medal Pangnegosyo 2 Program, Editha has successfully repaid a loan of PHP 5,000. 

She is now requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 as her fifth loan, which will be used for guso culture and production. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, repaying loans, educating the children and possibly expanding guso production.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

To make a living, she is engaged in the photocopying business. She’s been engaged in this kind of business activity for 15 years already. She’s earning an average amount of not less than PHP 3,000 a month.

As a newly recognized member of Paglaum MPC under the Medal Pangnegosyo 2 Program, she is now requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 as her first loan, which will be used for purchasing materials for her printing services. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, repaying loans and possibly expanding the  business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married man living with his wife and four kids. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a home painter for the past 24 years. He works on a freelance basis, taking home projects. His income is vital to support his family and be able to satisfy the heavy expenses of life. He has obtained his first Kiva loan and was a good client with payments on time. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $2000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new painting tools instead of his used ones to present good quality service to the clients. In the future, he hopes to further expand his business and continue his work properly to earn income for his family.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana S. is from the village of Pob. Manukan. She is 37 years old, married, and has seven school-aged children. 

Ana operates a family member's sari-sari (general) store in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase materials for her store renovation. 

Ana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products for her store. This will be the second loan taken out by Ana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional goods to sell

loans.name: Maria Lolita

Maria Lolita J. is from the village of Osukan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 61 years old. Maria Lolita is married and has four adult-aged children.

In 2011, Maria Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Maria Lolita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Maria Lolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Estrella's Group

texts.en:
Estrella M. is a 52-year-old woman from the village of Sipaloc, Sibutad. Estrella is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC). While both members of the group would receive an individual loan, they would be collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group member if one of them is delinquent or defaults.

Estrella is married and has two adult-age children. To earn a living, Estrella owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector. Specifically, she raises hogs to sell. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for many years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Estrella joined PMPC to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to improve her standard of living. Recently, Estrella successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase feed for her hogs. Estrella is now requesting a new loan, this time in the amount of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to build pig pens. Notably, this loan would be the seventh loan taken out by Estrella from PMPC.

About PMPC: PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To build pig pens

loans.name: Rosalie Rasonable Group's

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosalie R. is from the Barangay of Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. Rosalie is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC). While both members of the group would receive an individual loan, they would be collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group member if one of them is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosalie R.’s Group.

Rosalie is a married, 35-year-old woman who is blessed with one school-age child. To earn a living, she is engaged in the agriculture industry. Specifically, she produces seaweed (locally known as guso) for re-sale purposes. She has been engaged in this line of business for five years, and she typically earns an average of no less than 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2011, Rosalie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. By doing so, she hopes to be better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Rosalie is an active member of PMPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reaches out to rural communities. She is now requesting her first loan through PMP, in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which would be used to finance production of her guso. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve her family's living conditions. For instance, she would like to use the additional revenue to meet their family's basic needs, save for the future, repay the loan, and expand her business.

About PMPC: PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model

loans.use: To expand her guso (seaweed) production

loans.name: Maria Victoria's Group

texts.en:
Maria Victoria G. is a 47-year-old married woman from the village of Bañadero, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She and her husband have four school-age children. Maria is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC). While each member of the group would receive an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if one of them is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Maria Victoria’s Group.

To earn a living, Maria owns and operates a general store, where she sells a variety of products to her local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 per month from this activity.

In 2006, Maria joined PMPC to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Recently, she successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maria is now requesting a new loan, again in the amount of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as additional working capital. Notably, this would be her sixth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Lovely

texts.en:

To earn a living, Lovely operates a sari-sari (i.e., variety) store, where she sells goods directly to her local community members. Lovely has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2010, Lovely joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to improve her family's standard of living. Lovely is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which would be used as additional capital for her business. This would be the second loan taken out by Lovely from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC: PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To expand her business operations

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma C. is a 49-year-old, married woman. She and her husband do not have children, and they reside in Bagacay, Sibutad. To earn a living, she is engaged in the agriculture business. Specifically, her main source of income is derived from selling rice. She has been engaged in this business for many years and earns a monthly net income of approximately 2,500 PHP.

In 2007, Emma joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) to gain much-needed access to financial services. As a result, she was better able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her family's standard of living. Recently, Emma successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. The previous loan was used to expand her business. Emma is now requesting a new loan, this time in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($350), which would be used to purchase farm supplies. Notably, this loan would be the fifth loan taken out by Emma from PMPC.

About PMPC: PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old Lebanese single man. He lives with his parents and one sibling. He has been working as a farmer for 10 years. In 2005, he bought a plot of land and executed his own farming work. He cultivates all types of vegetables. He has obtained his first Kiva loan and he was very satisfied with the results.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1100 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to buy agricultural seeds. He notes that these purchases will allow him to increase his productivity and therefore his income. In the future, he is planning to start fruit gardening in order to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy agricultural seeds.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna S., is from the village of Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Edna is married and has two adult children. To make a living she has been working at her business for almost 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Edna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. Edna is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used for buy-out in Tudela Branch PMPC and the remaining additional capital of her business. This will be the 1st loan taken by Edna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her work to improve the general living conditions of her family.

 About PMPC:

loans.name: Ukweli Group

texts.fr: Chinvura H.  est entrepreneur, leader du groupe d’affaire Ukweli, âgée de 45 ans, veuve, mère de 11 enfants.Son mari fut décédé suite une courte maladie circonstancielle. La cliente Chinvura H. est vendeuse d’huile de palme. Elle expose ses marchandises au marché sectoriel de Birere,tout prêt de la mosquée musulmane. Il ya plus de 15 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds propre reçu d’un membre de sa famille. Vers 2007, elle bénéficia de premier crédit de l’IMF Hekima pour renforcer  son capital. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouvelles marchandises (3 bidons d’huile de palme).  En plus,elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et construire dignement une belle maison pour ses enfants. Selon elle, le crédit de Hekima lui a servi  de vivre dans des conditions de vie  socialement et spituellement acceptables et lui épargné des tentations de que bon nombre des veuves rencontrent dans leur vie. La cliente Chinvura H. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes veuves exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Ukweli est constitué de 45 membres.Cependant,il ya deux femmes clients qui détiennent leurs bébés à main.
texts.en: H. Chinvura is an entrepreneur and the leader of the Ukweli business group. She is 45 years old, a widow and mother to eleven children. Her husband died following a short circumstantial illness. This customer sells palm oil. She displays her goods at the market near to the Muslim mosque in the Birere district. She has been carrying out this activity for more than 15 years. She began it with funds received from a family member. Around 2007 she benefited from her first loan from IMF Hekima to strengthen her capital. This new loan will allow her to get new supplies (three containers of palm oil). Furthermore, she has an ambition to expand her business and construct a beautiful house for her children. According to her, the loan from Hekima has allowed her to live in socially and spiritually acceptable conditions and has saved her from the temptations that a large number of widows experience in their life. H. Chinvura thanks IMF Hekima for its actions dedicated to poor widows who are rejected by classic banks. The Ukweli group is made up of 45 members. However, there are two female customers in the photo who are holding their babies in their arms.

loans.use: to buy three containers of palm oil

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Leonila Lopez' Group

texts.en:
Leonila L. is from the village of Dimaluna, Ozamiz City Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old, is married and has one child. . Leonila is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Leonila L.’ Group".

To make a living, Leonila owns and operates a retail store where she sells both daily-use products and ready-to-wear clothes in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for six years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In July 2009, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Leonila from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living standard of her family. 



*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


About Group Loans
In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for her little retail store.

Having repaid her previous loan of 9,000.00 PHP from PMPC that was used to expand the business, she is requesting her sixth loan for 8,000 PHP to help renovate her house.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 43-year-old married man living in Chtoura with his wife and four children. 

Hasan has owned a bakery since 2006, with 20 years of experience in this field. Hasan specializes in Lebanese saj bread (Markouk) specially done  over charcoA. on domed convex metA. griddle called a "saj."  

Hasan is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua for the first time in order to do necessary painting and renovation to his shop. He also wants to buy tables and chairs to let customers sit and eat there. Hasan will introduce new saj receipes with speciA. ingredients. He is planning to expand his business more and more to change his small bakery to a big saj restaurant. He hopes he can make this dream come true.

loans.use: to do necessary renovation to his bakery

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy new tools for his business

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin O. N. is 35 years old and married. He and his wife have five children aged 3 to 19 years old, to whom they hope to give good educations to the university level. 

His business is located at a market at Nyalenda in Kisumu. Kisumu is the region of Kenya that harbors lake Victoria and is well known as the lake basin. 

He owns a retail shop called Salaben Mini Shop and sells general items to the local people. He says that his major challenge is financial constraints. However, he works hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to increase the stock of the items he sells to meet the demand of his customers. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He also sees himself owning a matatu (minibus) some day. He describes himself as trustworthy and customer-friendly.

loans.use: to buy rice, flour, detergents, beverages, etc., for resale

loans.name: Mairamkul's Group

texts.en:
Mairamkul A., 54, is the leader of this group. She and the other three members of the group are residents of a town called Toktogul. This town is a homeland for many talented Kyrgyz public people. This group of entrepreneurs also has a fair chance of making their hometown well-known for talents. 

Mairamkul is married and has three daughters. Her husband works in technical maintenance of the hydroelectric station “Kambar Ata.” 

For 21 years this couple has raised various types of cattle. The foundation was laid 21 years ago when Mairamkul’s husband spent his salary of 15,000 KGS on purchasing six head of cattle. 

Since then, for Mairamkul, cattle breeding has been the major activity, just like for anyone else in the neighborhood. At this moment, their monthly profit equals 5,000 KGS, most of which is spent on covering transportation and food costs. 

The purpose of Mairamkul’s loan is to buy more cattle for further breeding and reselling. Her future dreams are purchasing an automobile and land and boosting the number of cattle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. loans.use: to purchase more cattle

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes S. is from the village of P-10 Manabay, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Mercedes is separated and has one school age child. 

To make a living, Mercedes is engaged in video games and direct selling. Mercedes has been engaged in her business for over four year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

 In 2009, Mercedes joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Mercedes is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used for additional capital of her business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Mercedes from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and two siblings. He has been working as an event organizer since 2008. At the same time, he works as a DJ. He works independently upon customers’ request. He works hard each day in collaboration with his father to be able to support his family.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase musical instruments. He is very optimistic and would like to open his own shop in the near future where he can sell musical instruments and related accessories.

loans.use: to purchase musical instruments.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha O. is 59 years old, married and a mother of two adult children. She resides in Bitibut, Sapang Dalaga. Editha earns a living by growing assorted crops to sell. She can generate an income of 2500 a month out of this activity. She has been in this business for many years and is still operating at present. 

In 2004, Editha joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Editha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Editha is requesting an 8th loan of 14,900 PHP,  which will be used to own a parcel of cocoland.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry K., aged 29, is married to Sharon Chelano who is a household helper. Henry operates a general shop at Donholm which has many clients. This has been his business for 3 years and he earns a monthly profit of Kshs 10,000.

He was introduced to KADET through a marketing event conducted by KADET credit officers in Donholm Estate. This loan of Kshs 30,000 is Henry's first loan and he intends to use it to increase stocks of sugar, rice and cooking oil in his shop. He hopes that this loan will yield good returns which he plans to use to open another shop.

Henry dreams of opening a supermarket in the future and he describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: to add stocks of sugar, rice and cooking oil to his store

loans.name: Charlyn

texts.en:
Charlyn C. is from the village of Villa M. Tejero, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 31 years old. Charlyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Charlyn owns & operates a business providing construction services to local community members. Charlyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 50,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Charlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Charlyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Charlyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. Rose has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for eight years, and she works six days out of every week. She also has a job as a teacher and it is an additional source of income. Rose has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal and expand her business. The main business challenge for Rose is transportation and the rainy season. Her goal is to buy her own plot of land. Rose lives in a home which she rents and has access to electricity and piped  water .

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Esterlina

texts.en:
Mrs. Esterlina Y. J. is from the village of Pulot, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old. Esterlina is married to Johnas J. and they are blessed with three adult children. As of now, she is receiving monthly support from her son's work abroad. 

In August 2008, Esterlina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlina has successfully repaid a loan of 50,000 PHP.  Esterlina is now requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials for house repairs. 

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Swagira

texts.en:
Swagira N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children, two of whom are in school. Swagira has a business of selling clothes. She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days out of every week. Swagira has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more second hand clothes to sell.

The main business challenge for Swagirah is seasonality and ever increasing prices of clothes. Her goal is to build her own home and start importing clothes. Swagirah lives in a home that she rents.  She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Ninakan's Group

texts.ru:
Нинакан Жакыпова, 56, лидер этой группы. За свои 56 лет она успела прожить успешную и интенсивную жизнь. В этой женщине совмещены мать пятерых детей, преподавателем с большим стажем и опытная работница сельского хозяйства. Все ее дети , кроме младшего 24-летнего сына уже давно вылетели из родительского гнезда и машут крыльями по-своему. Младший сын вместе с отцом, работником налоговой управы местного поселка, активно следят за подобающим уходом скота. Разведению крупно-рогатого скота в Токтогуле благоприятствуют природно-климатические условия. Семья занимается разведением в обоих направлениях -молочного и мясного. Своеобразие климата позволяет семье перегонять скот по сезонным пастбищам: весной -из долин в предгорья, а на летний период в высокогорную зону, жайлоо. По мнению Нинакан этот бизнес обладает хорошей рентабельностью. Он был начат еще 15 лет назад, когда родители Нинакан подарили ей первую корову. С тех пор эта деятельность приносит ей и ее семье стабильный доход. Выручку от продажи скота Нинакан вкладывает обратно в оборот. Она просит кредит с целью приобрести холодильник, на который она давно не может отложить средства. 


        --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en:
Ninakan Z., 56 years old, is this group’s leader. During the 56 years, her life was successful and intensive. This woman’s life has many facets: she is a mother of five, a schoolteacher with many years of experience, and an experienced agricultural worker. All her children, aside from the youngest 24-year old son, have left the nest long time ago and now fly on their own. The youngest son together with his father, who works at the local tax collection agency of their town, take an active part in caring for the livestock. The Toktogul climate is auspicious for raising cattle. The family raises both  beef and dairy cattle. The unique local climate allows the family to drive their cattle to different pastures according to the season: in the spring from the  valley to the hills, and in the summer to the high mountain areas. 

Ninakan believes that this business is profitable. She launched this work 15 years ago, when Ninakan’s parents first  bought a cow for her. Since then this business bring stable income for her and her family. She reinvests her income in the business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase a refrigerator, as she has not been able to  set funds aside for this purchase for a long time.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: increase her inventory of new shoes.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margret K., who lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda, is married and has seven children, six of whom are students. For over six years Margret has operated a business selling beer and local brew seven days a week. Her main business challenge is thieves. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more more crates of beer and jerycans of local gin.

Margret lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer and jerycans of local gin

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Mrs. Tessie J. is from the village of Bañadero, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old. Tessie is married and has four Adult-age children. To make a living, Tessie owns and operates a mini-grocery and restaurant business. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In February 2011, Tessie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie is now requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used for additional capital in her mini-grocery and restaurant business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use and loan repayment.

 About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to have access to working capital.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario R. is from the village of  P-1 Labo, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, married, and has five adult children. To make a living, Rosario is engaged in barbecue vending . Rosario has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

 In 2011, Rosario joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosario is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used for additional capital of her business. This will be her first loan  from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine M. is 34 years old, married, and has five children. Christine is requesting her first loan from Kiva partner Vision Finance Company. She needs the loan to purchase more clothing to sell at her market stall. She has been in business for four years and has two employee in her shop. With her additional profits, Christine will buy a plot of land, build her own house, pay school fees for her children, and save for the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for her business.

loans.name: Jumagazy

texts.en:
Jumagazy A. is 51 years old, married, and has three children.  He works as a chair of the local administration and is known as a very responsible and hardworking person.  In order to find an additional means of subsistence, during the last 10 years Jumagazy has been engaged in cattle breeding.  With the initial capital of 10,000 KGS, he managed to earn 6,000–8,000 KGS in a month.  In the summer, he pastures in the mountainous areas, which allows him to reduce his expenses on the forage. With the revenues from this activity, Jumagazy paid for the education of his elder children. Jumagazy is requesting a loan of 50,000 KGS, which he will use to purchase sheep and one milch cow. Revenues from this activity will allow him to build a huge barn for his cattle.  

About Bai-Tushum and Partners Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy wood carvings and batik fabric

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives on his own. He is an experienced construction worker. He is especially talented at completing drywall work. He has been involved in this profession for the past 10 years. He started working independently in his field back in 2007.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase scaffolding and new tools needed for his work. In the future, he is planning to expand his business by opening a construction office and working with some construction entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase scaffolding and new tools.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open a new drugstore

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a married lady with a three-year-old child.  She operates a mobile-money transfer business for a living.  She has been running the business for eight years.  She was previously selling second-hand clothes.  She has improved her business through Faulu Kenya and now has better living standards.  She hopes to open another outlet of her business in the future.  She has requested  60,000 Kes to buy airtime float.

loans.use: To buy airtime float (cellular time)

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. Sofia has a  business of a retail shop . She has been in this business for five months, and she works seven days out of every week. Sofia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more merchandise, like bags of sugar, baking flour, and cooking oil.  The main business challenges for Sofia are the rainy season and transportation of merchandise from Kiuuubo in Kampal City to her shop in Ndeeba .

Sofia lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity but not to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise, like bags of sugar, cartons of salt , baking flour, maize flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en: Uranchimeg, 41, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a house on a small plot of land that they own. Her husband drives a taxi and earns 200,000 MNT monthly. Her younger son attends a local secondary school. They used to live in the countryside until their son grew to school age. They came to live in the city in 2000 and she began operating a retail business of food and groceries. In the beginning, she used to rent a stall at a food market and then she started operating a clothes sales business in 2004. She wants to expand her current business and increase her working capital. She is a hardworking and modest person who says, " I want to expand my business more and try to save money for my children's future studies". She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more clothes from China for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Ryskan's Group

texts.ru:
Рыскан Чимиянова,46, лидер этой группы. Услышав о замечательной возможности, предоставляемой Кивой, она немедленно поделилась этой информацией со своими коллегами. Сразу же образовалась группа единомышленников, которые нуждались в кредите. Чтобы найти применение своим умениям и стремлению работать на пользу себе и другим. Рыскан, мать четверых детей с заработной платой технички в 800 сомов начала свой бизнес 4 года назад с покупки одной козы. Рыскан совместными усилиями с мужем и 12-летним сыном достигли результата в 2 500 сомов месячной прибыли и увеличения поголовья коз до 20 голов. Рыскан хватает времени , навыков и сил, чтобы управиться с таким большим хозяйством. Она уверена что это еще не предел. С этой целью она и обратилась за кредитом. Рыскан хотела бы закупить дополнительно живности. 


        --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en:
Ryskan C. is 46 years old, the leader of this group. When she heard of the wonderful opportunity provided by Kiva she has immediately shared this information with her colleagues. The group of like minded people who needed a loan was formed at once to find use for their skills and to work rapidly for their own and others benefit.

Ryskan is a mother of four children with a technician's income of 800 soms. She started her business four years ago with the purchase of one goat. Ryskan together with her husband and their twelve year old son have achieved results of 2500 soms of monthly income and increased the head count of goats by 20 heads. Ryskan has the time, skills and strength to take care of such a large household. She is positive that this is not the limit. She is asking for a loan with this purpose. Ryskan wants to buy more livestock.

loans.use: to buy livestock

loans.name: Koudiratou

texts.fr: Mademoiselle Koudiratou a 31 ans. Elle est née à Lomé et habite quartier Akodessewa.  Elle vend les produits cosmétiques et les tapettes.  Elle compte  16 ans d’expérience et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Ensuite elle les revend à son domicile. Elle demande un crédit pour se réapprovisionner et accroître sa marge bénéficiaire.
texts.en: Miss Koudiratou is 31 years old. She was born in Lomé and lives in the Akodessewa district. She sells cosmetic products and flip-flops. She has 16 years experience and gets her supplies from the large market in Lomé. She then resells them from her home. She is requesting a loan to get fresh supplies and increase her profit margin.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetic products and flip-flops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more plumbing materials

loans.name: Zayat

texts.en: Zayat, 48, is widowed and lives with her son in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent.  Her son currently works in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She began sewing clothes in 1981 and worked for a few small companies that made and repaired clothes. She began operating her own clothing making business in 2006.  She wants to expand her business and open her own small factory in the future. She is a hardworking person who says, " I want to work with other tailors and operate a small clothing factory." She is requesting a loan of 550,000 MNT to purchase textile and cloth for her business.

loans.use: To purchase textile and cloth

loans.name: Kagnivi

texts.fr: Monsieur Kagnivi  est âgé de 24 ans. Il est né à Wogba et habite quartier Attiégou. Il fait le commerce de pièces détachées. Il a démarré cette activité en 2002 et achète les pièces dans les zones environnantes à Lomé.  Après il revend ces pièces à Akodessewa tout près de  Ecobank.  Il sollicite  un prêt pour acheter de nouveaux lots de pièces.
texts.en: Kagnivi is 24 years old. He was born in Wogba and lives in the Attiégou district. He buys and sells spare parts. He began this activity in 2002 and buys the various parts in the surroundings of  Lomé. Afterwards, he resells these parts in Akodessewa very close to Ecobank. He is requesting a loan to buy new batches of parts.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Cotilda

texts.en:
Cotilda Nakasi lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has four grown up children. Cotilda has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for five years, and she works seven days out of every week. Cotilda has requested for a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.

The main business challenge for Cotilda is the rainy seasonal and defaulters. She aspires to goto to villages for charcoal. Cotilda lives in a home that she owns; she does not have access to electricity or to piped water.  Her major monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson is a member of Gakuyu group registered under Faulu Kenya. Through Faulu Kenya, he saves his money and he can easily access business loans.  He sells shoes and second-hand clothes so in order to earn a living.  He was previously operating a retail shop.  He has been in the business for six years.  He hopes to open another branch of his business.  With 50, 000 Kes, he will add to his stock of shoes and clothes.

loans.use: To add to his stock of clothes and shoes

loans.name: Nyamirengyere Development Group-Kihihi

texts.en: 35 year old B. William makes common cause with Nyamirengyere Development group-Kihihi. 8 years is the time he has been running his food sales enterprise in Kihihi food market. The happily married father of three is a stickler for diligence and he cites it as the overriding factor as to why he has been able to make significant strides over the course of the last few years. He became involved in this business when he sensed the ready market for staple foods such as Irish potatoes, bananas, cassava, maize, beans, rice, etc in his home area. Before that, William worked in a timber sales business. By his own account, profits from this business enabled him to take root in his current business. Weekly his business generates him shillings 80,000 in profits. William is requesting this loan to purchase more food such as Irish potatoes, bananas, cassava, etc to resell.

loans.use: To purchase more food such as irish potatoes, cassava, bananas, etc to resell

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.ru:
Успех животноводства в Кыргызстане имеет несколько причин: наличие в стране естественных высокогорных пастбищ, отсутствие других сфер занятости в высокогорных районах и историческая традиция народа. 

Чолпон Суеркулова, 41, лидер этой группы. Недавно наша клиентка развелась и осталась с тремя дочерьми на воспитание. Проработав много лет в сфере медицины и посвятив все это время работе в больнице, Чолпон была вынуждена покинуть место работы так как новорожденный ребенок нуждался в постоянном уходе. Потратив отпускные и зарплату в 10 000 сомов на покупку трех голов мелкорогатого скота, Чолпон принялась осваивать новую профессию, разведение мелкорогатого скота. Имея всего лишь год опыта за плечами Чолпон неплохо освоилась в новом деле и имеет стабильную месячную прибыль в 5 000 сомов. Чолпон объясняет это устойчивым, даже постоянно растущим спросом на животноводческую продукцию в регионе и в целом мире. На данный момент
 Чолпон хочет построить наилучшие условия для своих дочерей. Цель кредита заключается в покупке мебели для дома. В этом году старшая дочь готовится к университетской жизни, и Чолпон надеется обеспечить ей достойное образование.

        --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en:
The success of animal husbandry in Kyrgyzstan stems from several sources:  the presence in the country of natural high-mountain pastures, the absence of other types of employment in mountainous areas, and the people’s history and tradition.

Cholpon S., 41, is the leader of this group. Recently, our client divorced and was left with three daughters to raise.  She has worked for many years in field of medicine and devoted all this time to working in a hospital.  Cholpon had to leave her work since her newborn baby requires constant care.  She spent her savings and salary (10,000 som) to buy three head of livestock.  Cholpon has begun to master a new trade: raising livestock.  After only one year of experience, Cholpon has not had trouble becoming accustomed to her new business.  She has a stable monthly income of 5,000 som. Cholpon explains that there is a steadily-growing demand for livestock production in that region and in the whole world. Cholpon wants to provide the best possible conditions for her daughters.  She is taking out a loan to purchase furniture for their house. This year, her oldest daughter is preparing to enter the university, and Cholpon hopes to provide her a solid foundation.

loans.use: to buy furniture

loans.name: Saruul

texts.en: Saruul, 48, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own. Her husband works for a construction company in the summer time. Her younger son attends a vocational school and gets a stipend of 45,000 MNT monthly. Her husband currently stays at home because he injured his legs at a construction site last summer. They used to keep livestock in the countryside until 1997, the year they came to live in the province center. Saruul began retail trading of meat in 1998 and she wants to expand her business. She is a modest and hardworking person who says, "I would like to expand my current business and increase my profit." She is requesting a loan of 500,000 MNT to purchase more meat to sell in the short run.

loans.use: to purchase more meat

loans.name: Phylles

texts.en: Phylles is a 34-year-old business lady who runs a retail shop. She mainly sells cereals and paraffin. She has 5 years of experience in the business. She also has other employment. Therefore, she has employed one person to run her business in her absence. Through Faulu Kenya, she has changed her living standards because of her improved business. She aspires to open a school in the future. She has requested 60,000 KES to buy paraffin and cereals.

loans.use: to buy paraffin and cereals

loans.name: C6303 Dukore Group

texts.en:
Jean is 60 years old and married, with six children between 7 and 21 years old. He is the president of a group called “Dukore." Jean sells rice, sugar, beans and other goods.  Others in the group have businesses selling beans at the local market. Jean employs two people in his business and has been working for three years in this business. He is the first person on the right side, wearing blue and black.

Jean and his group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders to buy more goods such as rice, sugar and beans to sell at the market. He would like to use any profits to start saving and to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To purchase goods such as rice, sugar and beans to sell

loans.name: Oyuntsetseg

texts.en:
Oyuntsetseg, 40, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they have owned for the past eight years.

Her husband works for a construction company and her older daughter helps her with the business while her son attends a local secondary school. Oyuntsetseg began a retail trading business at a local market in 2004. Now she sells used clothing and other items such as glasses and hats at her thriftshop that she rents currently. 

She wants to expand her business and increase her profit. She is a hardworking person with initiative who says, "I want to have my own store so that I can save money on rent and will be able to afford my son's future studies". She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) to purchase more used clothing and increase her inventory.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothing

loans.name: Amagalan

texts.en: Amagalan S. is 62 years old, married, and has one child.  They live in Gobi-Altai province of Mongolia. His wife is retired and stays at home.  His son attends college and drives a taxi in order to help his parents. Amgalan learned to make woodcraft items in 1967. He began operating a wood product-making business at home in 1990. He makes custom-ordered wooden furniture. He has a workshop which he purchased with his business revenues and is located in a crowded market. He currently operates his workshop and his business has become more stable. He supports his family and pays the tuition fees of his son with his income. Amgalan is teaching carpentry techniques to his son because he is planning to open a small factory of wood products in the future.  He is a hardworking person. He is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more wood and necessary materials for his woodcraft business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and other necessary materials

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Monsieur est marié et a 5 enfants. Il est âgé de  50 ans. Il est cambiste de profession pour répondre aux besoins de ses enfants. De plus, il a reçu de Wages un prêt qu’il a déjà remboursé. Il cumule 5 ans d’activité  et  satisfait les clients à la station shell à Akodessewa.  Il espère augmenter son capital et demande un crédit.
texts.en: This 50-year old man is married with five children. He exchanges money as a profession, in order to be able to provide for his children's needs. Furthermore, he has received a loan from Wages which he has already repaid. He has five years' experience in his business and serves his customers at the Shell station in Akodessewa. He is hoping to increase his capital and is thus requesting a loan.

loans.use: achat d'argent to buy money

loans.name: Sypaada's Group

texts.ru:
Сыпаада Жаманакова, 19, молодой лидер этой группы. В отличии от многих своих сверстников, она всегда точно знала чем она будет заниматься в жизни.
